articles.headline: Greek Far Right Hangs a Target on Immigrants
articles.snippet: Human rights groups say that xenophobic violence has reached “alarming proportions” in Greece since the rise of Golden Dawn, an extremist party, in the June election.
articles.abstract: Human rights groups say that xenophobic violence has reached “alarming proportions” in Greece since the rise of Golden Dawn, an extremist party, in the June election.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — A week after an extremist right-wing party gained an electoral foothold in Greece’s Parliament earlier this summer, 50 of its members riding motorbikes and armed with heavy wooden poles roared through Nikaia, a gritty suburb west of here, to telegraph their new power.

articles.headline: The Spreading Scourge of Corporate Corruption
articles.snippet: The misconduct of the financial industry no longer surprises most Americans, and trust in big business overall is declining. We should be alarmed.
articles.abstract: The misconduct of the financial industry no longer surprises most Americans, and trust in big business overall is declining. We should be alarmed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most surprising aspect of the Libor scandal is how familiar it seems. Sure, for some of the world’s leading banks to try to manipulate one of the most important interest rates in contemporary finance is clearly egregious. But is that worse than packaging billions of dollars worth of dubious mortgages into a bond and having it stamped with a Triple-A rating to sell to some dupe down the road while betting against it? Or how about forging documents on an industrial scale to foreclose fraudulently on countless homeowners?

articles.headline: Duke Energy’s Chief Defends Abrupt Dismissal of His Predecessor
articles.snippet: The chief of Duke Energy told regulators that the board had a list of worries about the man chosen to preside over the newly merged utility.
articles.abstract: The chief of Duke Energy told regulators that the board had a list of worries about the man chosen to preside over the newly merged utility.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — An accumulation of concerns caused Duke Energy’s board to lose confidence in its chief executive, leading to his ouster just hours after completing a $32 billion merger with Progress Energy, according to testimony Tuesday by the man who replaced him.

articles.headline: NBC and Facebook to Announce Olympics Partnership
articles.snippet: Viewers of NBC’s coverage will be encouraged to talk about the Games on Facebook, and Facebook users will be reminded to watch the coverage on NBC.
articles.abstract: Viewers of NBC’s coverage will be encouraged to talk about the Games on Facebook, and Facebook users will be reminded to watch the coverage on NBC.
articles.lead_paragraph: Users of Facebook, later this summer, will be reminded about NBC’s coverage of the Olympic Games in London. And viewers of NBC’s coverage, at the same time, will be nudged to talk about the Games on Facebook.

articles.headline: After Russian Floods, Grief, Rage and Deep Mistrust
articles.snippet: Officials acknowledged that they had been aware of a threat to Krymsk the night before deadly flooding, but had not taken measures to rouse its sleeping residents.
articles.abstract: Officials acknowledged that they had been aware of a threat to Krymsk the night before deadly flooding, but had not taken measures to rouse its sleeping residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: KRYMSK, Russia — Forty-six new graves were cut on Tuesday in a field outside this city, where catastrophic flooding has left behind a slime of mud and anger.

articles.headline: Philanthropist Couple’s Drug Downfall Ends in Death and Arrest
articles.snippet: Eva Rausing’s death appears to be the sorry denouement of years of struggle in which she and her husband, Hans, apparently never managed to shake their addictions.
articles.abstract: Eva Rausing’s death appears to be the sorry denouement of years of struggle in which she and her husband, Hans, apparently never managed to shake their addictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — They were lavishly generous patrons of drug treatment charities who turned out to be drug addicts themselves, a glitteringly wealthy couple whose secret lives were exposed four years ago when the police caught them with thousands of dollars’ worth of crack cocaine and heroin.

articles.headline: Insurers Pay Big Markups as Doctors Dispense Drugs
articles.snippet: Doctors operating their own in-office pharmacies are raising the costs for insurance companies, employers and taxpayers.
articles.abstract: Doctors operating their own in-office pharmacies are raising the costs for insurance companies, employers and taxpayers.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a pharmacy sells the heartburn drug Zantac, each pill costs about 35 cents. But doctors dispensing it to patients in their offices have charged nearly 10 times that price, or $3.25 a pill.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Katie Thomas
